qas.question: What arduous aspect of the process can designers skip in Multiwire?
What does the machine create by drawing a straight line between two points on the board?
Along with quick design times, what problem does Multiwire cut down on?
What makes Multiwire impractical to use when large quantities of a board are needed?
In simple language, what are the interconnections in an embedding matrix?
It was difficult to stack interconnections inside of what?
The machine will draw a wire in a curved line from one location/ to where?
What led to long design times?

context: Since it was quite easy to stack interconnections (<a4_0>wires<a4_0/>) inside <b5_0>the embedding matrix<b5_0/>, the approach allowed designers to forget completely about the <a0_0>routing of wires<a0_0/> (usually a time-consuming operation of PCB design): Anywhere the designer needs <a1_0>a connection<a1_0/>, <b7_0><b8_0>the machine<b8_0/><b7_0/> will draw a wire in straight line from one location/pin to <b6_0>another<b6_0/>. This led to very short design times (no complex algorithms to use even for high density designs) as well as reduced <a2_0>crosstalk<a2_0/> (which is worse when wires run parallel to each other—which almost never happens in Multiwire), though the <a3_0>cost<a3_0/> is too high to compete with cheaper PCB technologies when large quantities are needed.
